column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Mattheus van Beveren
#Text=St Nicholas with children in a tub flanked by angels , main altar of the Saint Nicholas ' Church , Ghent

#Text=Mattheus van Beveren ( alternative names : Mathieu Van Beveren , Mathieu Beveren , Matthieu Beveren ) ( c. 1630 , Antwerp – after 21 January 1696 , Brussels ) was a Flemish sculptor and medalist who is mainly known for his monumental Baroque church sculptures and small wood and ivory sculptures .
#Text=Life
#Text=Details about his life are scarce .
#Text=He likely trained with the Antwerp sculptor Pieter Verbrugghen I . [ 1 ]
#Text=He joined the Antwerp Guild of St. Luke in 1649/50 . [ 2 ]
#Text=He was the mint superintendent of Antwerp in the 1670s and 80s .
#Text=He married Suzanna Dooms , by whom he had a son named Judocus and a daughter named Catherina who married the flower still life painter Nicolaes van Verendael . [ 2 ] [ 3 ]
#Text=Mattheus van Beveren ran a large sculpture workshop with a significant output .
#Text=Mattheus van Beveren was highly recognized for his artistic work and contributions as an instructor . [ 4 ]
#Text=He trained Jan Baptist Santvoort . [ 2 ]
#Text=Work
#Text=Allegorical figures representing Virtue , Fame and Time , funerary chapel of Duke Lamoral of Thurn and Taxis
#Text=Van Beveren was a versatile artist in terms of the subject range of his sculptures as well as the materials in which he worked .
#Text=He executed monumental works in marble , stone and wood as well as small-scale works in wood , ivory and terracota .
#Text=He further was a medalist and produced designs for dies for the Antwerp Mint . [ 1 ]

#Text=Van Beveren 's style combines the classicist tendency of the Brussels sculptors Jerôme Duquesnoy ( I ) and his son François Duquesnoy with the baroque realism of his Antwerp contemporaries Pieter Verbrugghen II and Artus Quellinus the Younger who were more influenced by the style of Rubens . [ 1 ]
#Text=His subject matter was mainly religious but he also worked on portraits and allegorical subjects .

#Text=An example of the latter is the group of allegorical figures representing Virtue , Fame and Time created for the funerary chapel of Duke Lamoral of Thorn and Taxis ( in the Our Blessed Lady of Zavel Church in Brussels ) of which a terracotta model is kept at the Royal Museums of Fine Arts of Belgium in Brussels . [ 5 ] [ 6 ]
#Text=He executed the main altar in the St Nicholas Church in Ghent . [ 7 ]
#Text=He collaborated with some of the leading Flemish sculptors in the execution of large religious sculptures .
#Text=He assisted Lucas Faydherbe with the painted wood and stone high altar in the St Rumbold 's Cathedral in Mechelen . [ 1 ]
#Text=He made an Angel throne for the Antwerp Cathedral ( 1659 – 1660 ) after a design by Artus Quellinus the Younger . [ 8 ]
#Text=His designs were used by his large workshop and other contemporary artists in the creation of numerous sculptures .
#Text=The Brussels sculptor Jan Cosyns , for instance , sculpted the marble statues for the funerary chapel of Duke Lamoral of Thurn and Taxis after a design by van Beveren . [ 9 ]
#Text=Matheus van Beveren was known for his small-scale works , and in particular his ivory sculptures . [ 4 ]
#Text=Beautiful examples are the Cupid on a lion in the Metropolitan Museum of Art and the Maria Apocalyptica in the Rijksmuseum . [ 10 ] [ 11 ]
#Text=He and his workshop often used paintings by Rubens as models for numerous ivory crucifixes . [ 12 ]
#Text=Selected works
#Text=1665 : Pillar monument of Gaspard Boest in the Church of St. Jacob in Antwerp .
#Text=1677 – 1678 : Main altar of the Church of St. Nicolas in Ghent .
#Text=1678 : Marble tomb monument for Lamoral Claude-François , Count of Thurn and Taxis in the Our Blessed Lady of Zavel Church in Brussels .
#Text=1680 ca. : Madonna and Child with Maria and St. John the Evangelist , ivory , Amsterdam , Rijksmuseum .
#Text=1681 – 1684 : Wooden pulpit of the Church of Our Lady in Dendermonde .
#Text=Oak doors for the entrance to the Augustinian monastery in Tienen . [ 13 ]
